introduction.p: As water drains from a tank the drainage rate continually decreases over time. Suppose that a tank that initially holds 360 of water drains in exactly 6 minutes. Answer each of the following questions about this problem situation.

statement.p: Suppose that \fe{V}{t} is the amount of water () left in the tank where t is the amount of time that has elapsed () since the drainage began. What are the units on \fe{\fd{V}}{45} and \fe{\sd{V}}{45}? Which of the following is the most realistic value for \fe{\fd{V}}{45}?

solution.p: The unit for \fe{\fd{V}}{45} is and the unit for \fe{\sd{V}}{45} is \frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}. Since the amount of water left in the tank is decreasing, the value of \fe{\fd{V}}{45} cannot be positive. The average drainage rate is 60 which is equivalent to 1. Initially the tank drains faster than this average rate, and towards the end of the drainage the tank is draining slower than this average rate. Since 45 seconds is early in the drainage process the drainage rate is almost certainly greater than the average rate of 1. Hence the most realistic value for \fe{\fd{V}}{45} is -1.2.

answer.p: The unit for \fe{\fd{V}}{45} is and the unit for \fe{\sd{V}}{45} is \frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}. The most realistic value for \fe{\fd{V}}{45} is -1.2.

statement.p: Suppose that \fe{R}{t} is the water's flow rate () where t is the amount of time that has elapsed () since the drainage began. What are the units on \fe{\fd{R}}{45} and \fe{\sd{R}}{45}? Which of the following is the most realistic value for \fe{\fd{R}}{45}?

solution.p: The unit for \fe{\fd{R}}{45} is \frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}, and the unit for \fe{\sd{R}}{45} is \sfrac{\frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}. The average drainage rate is 60 which is equivalent to 1. Initially the tank drains faster than this average rate, and towards the end of the drainage the tank is draining slower than this average rate. Since the flow rate ecreases over time, the value of \fe{\fd{R}}{45} cannot be positive. Since the average flow rate over the 360 seconds is 1, it is not believable that 45 seconds into the process the flow rate was decreasing at a rate of 1\,\frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}. Hence the most realistic value for \fe{\fd{R}}{45} is -0.001.

answer.p: The unit for \fe{\fd{R}}{45} is \frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}, and the unit for \fe{\sd{R}}{45} is \sfrac{\frac{\sfrac{\text{gal}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}}{\text{s}}. The most realistic value for \fe{\fd{R}}{45} is -0.001.

statement.p: Suppose that \fe{V}{t} is the amount of water ()left in the tank where t is the amount of time that has elapsed () since the drainage began. Which of the following is the most realistic value for \fe{\sd{V}}{45}?

solution.p: Because V is defined as the amount of water left in the tank, \fd{V}=-R. So \sd{V}=-\fd{R}, and then the answer here is just the negative of the previous answer, using the same reasoning.The most realistic value for \fe{\sd{V}}{45} is 0.001.

answer.p: The most realistic value for \fe{\sd{V}}{45} is 0.001.

introduction.p: For each statement in , decide which of the following is true.

ol.li: The statement is true regardless of the specific function f.
The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.
The statement is false regardless of the specific function f.

statement.p: If a function f is increasing over the entire interval \ointerval{-3}{7} and \fe{\fd{f}}{0} exists, then \fe{\fd{f}}{0}\gt0.

solution.p: For some functions, \fe{\fd{f}}{0} may be 0. For say a linear increasing function, the statement would be true. So the statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

answer.p: The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

statement.p: If a function f is increasing over the entire interval \ointerval{-3}{7} and \fe{\fd{f}}{4} exists, then \fe{\fd{f}}{4}=0.

solution.p: Imagine a function like (x-4)^3, where the statement is true. For a linear increasing function, the statement would be false. So the statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

answer.p: The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

statement.p: If a function f is concave down over the entire interval \ointerval{-3}{7} and \fe{\fd{f}}{-2} exists, then \fe{\fd{f}}{-2}\lt0.

solution.p: It's easy to imagine functions where this would be true, but there are also functions where \fe{\fd{f}}{-2} is 0. So the statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

answer.p: The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

statement.p: If the slope of f is increasing over the entire interval \ointerval{-3}{7} and \fe{\fd{f}}{0} exists, then \fe{\fd{f}}{0}\gt0.

solution.p: This tells us that f is concave up, so \fe{\sd{f}}{x}\geq0, but \fe{\fd{f}}{x} could still be anything. So the statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

answer.p: The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

statement.p: If a function f has a local maximum at 3, then \fe{\fd{f}}{3}=0.

solution.p: It's easy to imagine functions where this would be true, like -(x-3)^2. But there are also functions where there is a maximum at 3 and \fe{\fd{f}}{3} doesn't even exist, like -|x-3|. So the statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

answer.p: The statement is true for some functions and false for other functions.

introduction.p: For a certain function g, \fe{\fd{g}}{t}=-8 at all values of t on \ointerval{-\infty}{-3} and \fe{\fd{g}}{t}=2 at all values of t on \ointerval{-3}{\infty}.

statement.p: Janice thinks that g must be discontinuous at -3 but Lisa disagrees. Who's right?

solution.p: Lisa is right. Maybe g is discontinuous at -3, but maybe it simply is pointy at -3.

statement.p: Lisa thinks that the graph of \sd{g} is the line y=0 but Janice disagrees. Who's right?

solution.p: Janice is right although Lisa is pretty darn close to being right. The graph of \sd{g} is basically the line y=0, but because \fd{g} is nondifferentiable at -3, \sd{g} has a hole at -3.

paragraphs.p: Each statement below is in reference to the function shown in . Decide whether each statement is true or false. A caption has been omitted from because the identity of the curve changes from question to question.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is \fd{f}, then \fe{f}{3}\gt\fe{f}{2}.

solution.p: \fe{\fd{f}}{t} is negative on \ointerval{2}{3}, so f is decreasing on \ointerval{2}{3}, and therefore \fe{f}{3}\lt\fe{f}{2}. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is f, then \fe{\fd{f}}{3}\gt\fe{\fd{f}}{2}.

solution.p: We can see that \fe{\fd{f}}{2} is 0, while \fe{\fd{f}}{3} is positive. So the statement is true.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is f, then \fe{\fd{f}}{1}\gt\fe{\sd{f}}{1}.

solution.p: We can see that \fe{\fd{f}}{1} is negative because the function is decreasing there. And we can see that \fe{\sd{f}}{1} is positive because the function is concave up there. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is \fd{f}, then the tangent line to f at 6 is horizontal.

solution.p: \fe{\fd{f}}{6} is negative, so the tangent line to f at 6 has negative slope. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is \fd{f}, then \sd{f} is always increasing.

solution.p: At points immediately to the left of 4, \sd{f} would be positive, and at points immediately to the right of 4, \sd{f} would be negative. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is \fd{f}, then f is not differentiable at 4.

solution.p: It appears that \fe{\fd{f}}{4} is defined, with a value of about 4.25. So f is differentiable at 4. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is \fd{f}, then \fd{f} is not differentiable at 4.

solution.p: It appears that \fe{\fd{f}}{4} is undefined because the limit of secant slopes from the left is positive, while the limit from the right is negative. So the statement is true.

statement.p: True or False? The first derivative of the given function is periodic (starting at 0).

solution.p: Since the tangent slope anywhere (except multiples of 4, where the tangent slope is undefined) is equal to the tangent slope 4 units forward, the derivative is periodic with period 4. So the statement is true.

statement.p: True or False? Antiderivatives of the given function are periodic (starting at 0).

solution.p: An antiderivative would be increasing over half of each period, and decreasing over the other half. But it would be increasing more steeply in general while it is increasing compared to where it is decreasing. So over each period, there will be a net rise. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function was measuring the rate at which the volume of air in your lungs was changing t seconds after you were frightened, then there was the same amount of air in your lungs 9 seconds after the fright as was there 7 seconds after the fright.

solution.p: The amount of air in your lungs was increasing the entire two seconds. So the statement is false.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is measuring the position of a weight attached to a spring relative to a table edge (with positive and negative positions corresponding, respectively, to the weight being above and below the edge of the table), then the weight is in the same position 9 seconds after it begins to bob as it is 7 seconds after the bobbing commenced (assuming that t represents the number of seconds that pass after the weight begins to bob).

solution.p: At both of these times, the weight is level with the table. So the statement is true.

statement.p: True or False? If the given function is measuring the velocity of a weight attached to a spring relative to a table edge (with positive and negative positions corresponding, respectively, to the weight being above and below the edge of the table), then the spring was moving downward over the interval \ointerval{1}{3} (assuming that t represents the number of seconds that pass after the weight begins to bob).

solution.p: Negative velocity corresponds to downward motion (because the position is decreasing when the velocity is negative). So the statement is true.

statement.p: Suppose \fe{f}{-3}=14. What is the equation of the tangent line to f at -3?

solution.p: Since the slope of f at -3 is \fe{\fd{f}}{-3}=-4, the equation of the tangent line to f at -3 is y=-4(x+3)+14.
